name: Pilsen (Plze켿)
fun_fact: Fun fact: Pilsen literally revolutionized global beer culture! On October 5, 1842, Bavarian brewmaster Josef Groll brewed the world's first pale lager here, creating golden Pilsner Urquell. Before this, all beer was murky and dark. Pilsen's soft water, Saaz hops, and Moravian barley created a clear, golden beer so extraordinary it shocked even Groll himself. Today, 9 out of 10 beers worldwide are pale lagers based on this Pilsen original!

hero_dishes.name: Pilsner Urquell (Unfiltered from the Barrel)
hero_dishes.description: The world's original Pilsner beer, tapped fresh from oak barrels in the historic underground cellars. Unfiltered, unpasteurized, and served at 7춿C exactly as it tasted in 1842 - golden, crisp, hoppy, with a creamy head.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created on October 5, 1842, when disgruntled Pilsen citizens dumped barrels of terrible beer in protest and hired Josef Groll to make something better. Using Pilsen's remarkably soft water, local Saaz hops, Moravian barley malt, and Bavarian bottom-fermentation, Groll created the first clear golden lager. The beer was so revolutionary that by 1853 it reached 35 Prague pubs, Vienna by 1856, Paris by 1862. The name 'Pilsner Urquell' (meaning 'original source') was trademarked in 1898.

hero_dishes.name: Czech Goulash (Gul치코)
hero_dishes.description: Rich, hearty beef stew slow-cooked with paprika, onions, and Czech spices. Served with knedl칤ky (bread dumplings) to soak up the thick, flavorful sauce. Pairs perfectly with Pilsner beer.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Adapted from Hungarian goulash, the Czech version is thicker and heartier - perfect fuel for extended Pilsner drinking sessions.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Na Park치nu pub (traditional beer-matched meals), Na Spilce (Bohemia's largest gastropub with 550 seats)

hero_dishes.name: Sv칤캜kov치 (Sirloin in Cream Sauce)
hero_dishes.description: Tender beef sirloin in rich cream sauce with root vegetables, served with bread dumplings and cranberry sauce. A Czech national treasure.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Classic Czech dish dating back centuries, adapted from Austrian Habsburgs when Bohemia was ruled by Austrian King Ferdinand I from the 16th century.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: U Salzmann콢 (Pilsen's oldest pub, opened 1637 - stylish atmosphere with traditional Czech specialties)

hero_dishes.name: Roast Pork with Sauerkraut and Dumplings
hero_dishes.description: Vep콏o-knedlo-zelo - the quintessential Czech comfort food. Juicy roasted pork, tangy sauerkraut, and fluffy bread dumplings.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Sauerkraut and dumplings were adopted from German neighbors and became Czech classics. The stodgy, meat-heavy meal is the perfect thing to sustain you through extended drinking sessions.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional pubs throughout Pilsen - pairs perfectly with Pilsner beer

signature_drinks.name: Pilsner Urquell (from the tap)
signature_drinks.description: The grandfather of all lager beers, brewed the same way since 1842. Golden color, crisp taste, noble Saaz hop bitterness, 4.4% ABV. Still uses open fermenters and oak barrel maturation.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in proper Czech beer glasses with a thick creamy head. Locals drink it slowly, appreciating the craftsmanship. The brewery still employs 8 master coopers who handcraft oak barrels using traditional techniques passed down from master to apprentice.

signature_drinks.name: Becherovka
signature_drinks.description: Czech herbal liqueur from nearby Karlovy Vary - often enjoyed as a digestif after heavy Czech meals.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Shot after dinner, or mixed with tonic as 'Beton' (concrete) for a refreshing long drink.

food_culture_notes: Pilsen is more famous for beer than cuisine, but Czechs pair food with beer (not the other way around!)

Schnitzels and strudels became Czech staples during Habsburg Austrian rule (16th century onward)
Martin Salzmann, founder of U Salzmann콢 restaurant, was the first person to carry a barrel of Pilsner Urquell to Prague in 1843!
